titleStmt.title: Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality

analytic.title: Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: We present artificial intelligent (AI) agents that act as interviewers to engage with a user in a text-based conversation and automatically infer the user's personality traits. We investigate how the personality of an AI interviewer and the inferred personality of a user influences the user's trust in the AI interviewer from two perspectives: the user's willingness to confide in and listen to an AI interviewer. We have developed two AI interviewers with distinct personalities and deployed them in a series of real-world events. We present findings from four such deployments involving 1,280 users, including 606 actual job applicants. Notably, users are more willing to confide in and listen to an AI interviewer with a serious, assertive personality in a highstakes job interview. Moreover, users' personality traits, inferred from their chat text, along with interview context, influence their perception of and their willingness to confide in and listen to an AI interviewer. Finally, we discuss the design implications of our work on building hyper-personalized, intelligent agents.
CCS Concepts: • Human-centered computing → Interactive systems and tools; • Computing methodologies → Intelligent agents;

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: In a wide variety of domains, including human capital management and patient care, interviewing is often used to collect information from target respondents and to assess certain characteristics of the respondents. For example, a hiring manager may interview a pool of job applicants over the phone to discover their career interests and assess their characteristics, such as personality and motivations, before determining their fit for the position.

While a human interviewer can gather in-depth information, it presents several limitations. First, it is difficult to scale since a human interviewer can interview only one person at a time 10:2 M. X. Zhou et al. and conduct only a limited number of interviews per day. Second, research shows that a human interviewer's personal factors, such as personality, can affect interview results (e.g., see Refs [45,106]). Third, respondents may not feel comfortable disclosing sensitive information to human interviewers due to social desirability biases [59].

To overcome the limitations of a human interviewer while providing a personal touch, we have built artificial intelligence (AI) interviewers that conduct one-on-one interviews via text-based conversations. Figure 1 shows a screenshot where an AI interviewer (Kaya) conducts a text-based interview with a user (James). During such an interview, Kaya also automatically infers James's characteristics, such as personality traits, based on his chat text given during the interview.

Our decision to support a text-only conversation is based on three considerations. First, with the increasing use of cell phones and social media, more and more people use text-based communication, also known as texting. A Gallup poll 1 shows that texting is the dominant communication method for Americans under 50. We thus wish to support human-computer conversations in a modality that most people are familiar with. Second, an interview is often a private activity, especially in a high-stakes context such as job interviewing. Text-only interaction not only keeps a user focused on the interview without distractions [48,86], but also lets the user do so discreetly without disturbing others nearby as a voice-based interaction might. Third, although significant technical advances have been made to support human-computer interactions in richer modalities such as voice and gestures (e.g., see Refs [22,75]), the technologies including those used in commercial systems like Apple Siri, Amazon Alexa, and Google Now are far from being perfect [25,60,93,102]. Given our goal of deploying AI interviewers for real-world use, we decided to support text-only conversations to minimize potential system errors due to technology imperfections (e.g., speech recognition errors due to user accent or a noisy surrounding).
Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality 10:3

Compared to a human interviewer, an AI interviewer has two distinct advantages. First, it does not experience fatigue and can scale to interview hundreds of thousands of users simultaneously. Second, it can render a more objective, unbiased assessment, since it does not bring personal emotions or human prejudice into an interview as a human interviewer might (e.g., affect heuristic [107]).

Since studies show that interviewers' personalities directly affect interview outcomes [45,106], one of our tasks is to equip an AI interviewer with the "personality" of an effective interviewer. This is non-trivial for three reasons. First, existing research suggests that computers should take on one strong, consistent personality [78]. However, it is unclear which personality an AI interviewer should assume in order to achieve multiple interview goals. For example, a warm and cheerful personality may aid in building rapport with human respondents who can then relax and act authentically [9,59]. On the other hand, a more serious and assertive personality may elicit more respect and better cooperation from the respondents [45,77]. Second, existing systems stress the use of both verbal and non-verbal cues to express an agent's personality [54,87,77]. However, it is unclear how an AI interviewer can effectively exhibit its personality through text-only expressions. Third, unlike most AI agents, which are used in a laboratory setting, ours will be used in the real world, including high-stakes situations, such as job interviews. It is unknown how an agent's personality would affect users in such a context.

To address the challenges mentioned above, as the first step, we decided to give each AI interviewer a strong, consistent personality as suggested by existing work [78]. We built two AI interviewers -called Responsible and Empathetic Personas (REPs), with two distinct personalities, each aimed at achieving a key interview goal. One is a female persona (Kaya) with a warm and cheerful personality, while the other is a male persona (Albert) with a reserved and assertive personality. Based on existing work and through various deployments of Kaya and Albert, we hope to answer three research questions:

• R1: How does the personality of an agent impact user's willingness to confide in that REP? • R2: How does the personality of an agent impact users' willingness to listen to that REP? • R3: How do other factors, such as interview context and users' individual differences, including personality traits, impact their behavior with an agent?

We have deployed our AI interviewers for a number of uses. Here, we use the results of four real-world deployments to answer research questions mentioned above. In all four deployments, our AI interviewers asked a series of questions to collect information from target respondents and inferred the respondents' Big 5 personality traits-the most widely used personality model [23] based on their responses. The first deployment used both Kaya and Albert to help an organization interview and pre-screen job applicants. In this deployment, 157 applicants finished their interview with Kaya, and 159 completed theirs with Albert. Another three deployments all used Kaya to interview target respondents for varied purposes: (a) interviewing and pre-screening summer internship applicants (290 completed interviews), (b) interviewing university students to elicit their team experience and preferences and infer their characteristics to facilitate project teaming (201 completed interviews), and (c) interviewing university students to assess student characteristics for educational purposes (473 completed interviews).

As seen later, our work offers two unique contributions. First, we present novel, practical approaches to building effective AI interviewers for real-world uses. In particular, we have built a topic-based conversation engine that can reliably support the completion of hour-long structured interviews. Moreover, our approach allows easy and fast customization of an AI interviewer to suit diverse interview scenarios, which helps the real-world adoption of such agents. Our AI interviewers can also dynamically analyze users' responses to automatically assess their characteristics on the fly and incorporate the inferred user characteristics into the interview to make an interview more engaging.

Second, the results of our analyses of the four deployments reveal several new insights in understanding users' trust in intelligent agents in real-world settings. Specifically, the personality of an agent affects users' willingness to confide in and listen to the REP. Furthermore, users' personality traits inferred by an agent influence their perception of and behavior with the agent. As a result, these findings inform design implications for building hyper-personalized agents.

div.head: RELATED WORK
div.p: Our work is built upon numerous existing efforts on studying and building effective virtual agents across multiple disciplines, from Psychology to Communications to Computer Science. These related efforts broadly fall in the following areas.

div.head: Computer Anthropomorphism and User Behavior
div.p: Our work builds AI interviewers that can influence and guide a user's behavior (e.g., truth telling). It is directly related to a rich body of research on examining how humans respond to computers with varied human-like characteristics. One line of studies focuses on how humans apply similar social rules used in the real world to computers as social actors. For example, Nass and his colleagues show that computer agents elicit users' social attributions, which are different based on the characteristics of the agents (e.g., the type of computer voice used) [69,78]. In another example, Fogg and Nass use a laboratory experiment to show that humans enjoy the flattery from computers as much as from other humans [28].

In addition to understanding human social behavior around computers, another extensive line of work examines humans' responses to computers with more expressive, human-like qualities, such as faces and facial expressions. In general, these studies have found that anthropomorphic properties of computers influence users' perceptions (e.g., [13,70,86]), attitude (e.g., [13]), and behavior around such systems (e.g., [48,86,105]). For example, Sproull et al. [86] report that people respond to a text-based interface differently than to a talking face. On the one hand, users are aroused more and present themselves more positively when interacting with a talking face. On the other hand, users are less relaxed or assured when interacting with a talking face. Another study shows that users find the interface with the anthropomorphic qualities-faces and facial expressions-more likeable and engaging, although such an interface takes the users' effort to interpret the meaning of the human-like expressions and may even be a distraction [48,86]. More recent studies show that human-like features with higher realism elicit more positive social interactions while having no significant impact on user task performance [105]. Furthermore, a study reveals that anthropomorphism may even elicit user objections due to users' own biases (e.g., sexism) [70].

Our work draws upon findings from these existing efforts. For example, we decide to support a text-only conversation to minimize potential user distraction or unnecessary biases rising from interpreting human-like expressions of an agent (e.g., feeling judged). Additionally, we focus on instilling specific intelligence and behavior into our agents so that they can function robustly to accomplish real-world tasks effectively (e.g., job interviews).

div.head: Computer Personality and User Personality
div.p: Human users often attribute personality to a machine with anthropomorphic characteristics. To understand how user-perceived machine personality influences user behavior, there are numerous efforts investigating the relationships among machine personality, user personality, and tasks (e.g., see Refs [13,24,54,68,87]). For example, multiple studies find that users favor a computer with a strong, consistent personality [68,87]. Moreover, users favor machines with a personality that Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality 10:5 matches their own personality [68]. However, in human-robot interaction, studies show conflicting results. For example, Lee et al. [54] indicate that users enjoy interacting with a robot with a complementary personality, while Tapus et al. [87] show that users prefer to interact with a robot with a matching personality. Moreover, studies find that users expect the personality of an agent to match the task context, e.g., a serious agent for a serious task [77], which directly influences users' willingness to comply with the agent's instructions.

Existing studies provide insights into the effects of an agent's personality on user behavior in various laboratory situations. However, it is unknown what personality an AI interviewer should take on and how its personality would impact its interviewees, especially in real-world situations, including high-stakes contexts like job interviews. Therefore, our work aims at answering this line of questions.

div.head: Intelligent Virtual Agents for Interviewing
div.p: Our effort of building AI interviewers is directly related to a line of work on developing embodied "virtual human interviewers" (e.g., see Refs [22,30,46,59,71]). Closest to our effort, DeVault et al. [22] built a virtual human interviewer to conduct interviews and assess distress indicators of users by analyzing their verbal and non-verbal behavior. Similarly, Nunamaker et al. have developed an information kiosk that acts as a conversational agent to interview users and detect their affective state and behavior. While our goals are similar in evaluating users' characteristics through an AI interview, our focus is different. Specifically, our work analyzes a user's communication behavior to infer the user's innate psychological characteristics such as personality, while theirs is on detecting changes in one's behavior during the interaction (e.g., arousal or distress).

div.head: Relational Agents
div.p: Since our work studies users' trust in virtual agents, it is related to numerous efforts on building trustworthy, relational agents (e.g., see Refs [9,10,46]). For example, researchers have built relational agents to interact with patients to encourage behavioral change [9] or coach a user on her/his interview behavior [46].

Our current effort is built on prior work of building relational agents. For example, our AI interviewer uses introductory questions [59] and reciprocal self-disclosure [9] in relational agents to build rapport with a user, and adopts different agents' personas to influence users' behavior [30,46]. However, our work differs in several aspects. First, since most relational agents are built to perform coaching or counseling tasks, existing efforts focus on instrumenting social skills of such an agent to build connections with users. In contrast, the primary purpose of ours is to conduct interviews and we focus on their ability to effectively elicit information in a conversation. Second, unlike most relational agents that employ both verbal and non-verbal cues to exhibit their personas, ours must present a strong, consistent personality via text-only communication. As discussed later, our work addresses unique challenges that have not been addressed before, which in turn makes unique contributions to building effective AI interviewers for real-world tasks.

div.head: Synthesis of Machine Personality
div.p: Our work on instilling a personality into an AI interviewer is related to various efforts on automated synthesis of machine personality. As indicated by a research survey on machine personality synthesis [95], there are three types of effort in general. One type of effort is to exhibit a machine's personality through synthetic voice by manipulating various prosodic features, such as pitch and speaking rate (e.g., see Refs [82,92]). The second type is to display a virtual agent's personality through various agent properties, including physical appearance, body movement, and language use (e.g., see Refs [5,65]). The third type is to instrument a physical robot's personality through its interaction behavior with users, such as speech, gaze, and physical distance to users (e.g., see Refs [3,87]).

In addition to these efforts, there are theories on building dialog agents with a personality through verbal communication [11,81]. Since our virtual interviewer engages a user in a textbased communication, our current work is closest to the efforts on using various verbal cues to display machine personality [11,81]. While we leverage the findings in such work, we also extend these efforts to create machine personality through additional behavior specific to interviewing (e.g., questioning and response style).

div.head: Inference of User Personality
div.p: Our work on automatically inferring a user's personality traits from the user's text communication during a virtual interview is inspired by numerous recent efforts on studying the relationships between users' traits and their communication behavior (e.g., see Refs [63,88,104,47,49,76]). For example, research indicates that words or word categories in users' blogs and essays are correlated with self-reported or third-party-rated personality traits [63,88,104]. More recent studies show that users' vocabulary and social media behavior, such as Facebook and Twitter, are also related to self-reported personality traits [47,49,76]. In addition to words, word categories, and social media behavior, researchers have also examined how voices (e.g., see Refs [44,56]), images (e.g., see Refs [2,58]), and videos (e.g., see Refs [8,56]) are related to personality traits.

Closest to our current effort is on computational models to automatically infer one's personality traits from the text generated by the person (e.g., see Refs [1,35,62]). Broadly, there are two main types of computational models [95]. One type uses various classification algorithms to determine whether one's personality trait falls into a particular category (e.g., high or low Extroversion) (e.g., see Refs [4,31]). For example, Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count (LIWC)2 word categories are used to classify whether a blogger is "high," "medium," or "low" on each of the Big 5 Personality traits based on the words used in blogs [31]. The other type of effort is to use various machine learning methods, mainly regression algorithms, to predict one's personality trait scores based on various user behavior (e.g., see Refs [51,76]). For example, a recent study uses regression algorithms to predict one's Dark Triad3 personality scores using a combination of Twitter content, profile image, and usage behavior (e.g., number of followers) [76].

Similar to the second type of computational models, ours automatically infers a user's personality trait scores from text. Existing models infer user traits by correlating users' self-reported psychometric test scores with their text footprints (e.g., see Refs [1,35,51,62]). In contrast, we gather "ground-truth" data (Section 4.1, step 1) to train our model because gathering self-reported scores is expensive and may not be authentic. As a result, our approach is more objective and cost-efficient, since it no longer requires a large sample of self-reported psychometric scores.

div.head: Practical Approaches to Conversational Agents
div.p: There are numerous computational approaches to conversational agents, including rule-based and data-driven (deep learning) approaches [91]. Given our goal of building agents for real-world uses, our work is most related to numerous efforts on creating commercial grade conversational agents, such as Amazon Alexa, Google Allo, Microsoft Cortana, and Apple Siri. Most of these Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality 10:7 conversational agents serve as a user's personal assistant to perform specific tasks, such as making a call or controlling a home device, based on the user's verbal requests. Most task-oriented agents are powered by rules [91]. Recently, deep learning techniques are used to train retrieval models for social agents, where the most probable response is retrieved from a repository of predefined responses given a user's request [103]. Alternatively, researchers build generative models (e.g., see Refs [96,84,85]). While these models can produce machine responses that never existed before, the quality of the generated responses does not work well in practice yet.

Compared to the existing efforts of creating AI agents, our goal is to create AI interviewers who can work well in practice, effectively carrying out a conversation to elicit information from a user and assess the user's characteristics. Neither retrieval-based nor generative models are practical for us, since they require huge amounts of training data [103] and it is difficult to obtain interview data as training data, not mentioning that such training data must cover varied interview contexts and diverse user responses given in an interview [22]. We thus have developed a rule-based approach with algorithms to manage an interview conversation (Section 6).

div.head: SYSTEM OVERVIEW
div.p: Figure 2 shows an overview of our system that supports automated interviews. An AI interviewer engages a user (interviewee) in a text-based conversation (c), powered by two core engines: (a) a personality engine and (b) a conversation engine. The personality engine analyzes a user's interaction behavior and automatically infers the user's personality traits and beyond, such as strengths and weaknesses. The conversation engine enables an AI interviewer to engage a user in a mixedinitiative conversation. Similar to a human interviewer, an AI interviewer takes initiatives to guide the interview flow and solicit information from a user, while it allows the user to pose questions whenever appropriate. For example, a user may ask a clarification question or inquire about the position that s/he is applying for. In such a case, the conversation engine first interprets the user's request and then decides how to respond to the request.

To help business users (e.g., a hiring manager or a market researcher) use interview results to make decisions, we provide an interactive visual dashboard that summarizes interview results (d). Figure 3(a) is a screenshot of such a visual dashboard that shows the number of interviewees who complete an interview and the derived Big 5 personality trait scores for the interviewees. Figure 3(b) displays a more detailed summary for a particular trait, including individuals' scores for that trait. Our system also maintains several databases (DB) and knowledge bases (KB), which store various types of information, such as users' answers to interview questions and inferred user traits.

div.head: EVIDENCE-BASED PERSONALITY ENGINE
div.p: To automatically infer a user's traits from text, most existing approaches use the uncovered correlations between word categories (i.e., LIWC categories) and self-reported personality trait scores (e.g., see Refs [1,35,62]). While these approaches have demonstrated their effectiveness in various applications (e.g., see Refs [55,61,62]), they have three main limitations. First, while using word categories is simple, the inference is coarse. This is because different words belonging to the same word category have the same weight, but their relationships to a trait may be quite different [104]. Moreover, there are a limited number of word categories (68 word categories in LIWC), and many word categories may not show significant correlations with a trait. Second, the correlations are derived based on one's word use and self-reported personality test scores, which may not be completely truthful [108]. Third, many of these approaches consider only single words but ignore other important linguistic cues, such as phrases, and punctuations, which may also reflect one's traits.

div.head: Approach
div.p: To overcome these limitations, we have developed an evidence-based approach to inferring a user's traits from the user's text. Below we highlight its three main steps.

Step 1: Gathering Trait-Related Evidence To build a personality inference engine, we first gather training data-user behavioral data that captures people's real-world activities that reflect their associated characteristics. Using the Twitter Application Programming Interface (API), we have collected tweets from 15 million Twitter users, each with up to 3,200 tweets. We then randomly sampled 1 million Twitter users and used their tweets as our training data. There are three reasons why we chose to use Twitter data as our training data. First, Twitter data is publicly available and abundant. Second, not only does Twitter data cover diverse topics, from politics to entertainment, but it is also generated by a diverse population, from retirees to presidents. Such diversity helps avoid potential data biases. Third, existing work, including our own, shows the effectiveness of Twitter data for measuring personality traits (e.g., see Refs [1,35,51,62]).

Given the dataset, tweets were examined and identified as potential trait-related evidence based on existing findings in the literature on personality assessment. For example, DeYoung et al. [20] indicate that a person high on Artistic Interests (a facet of Openness, one of the Big 5 personality factors) enjoys music and poetry. Based on this finding, we can mark two sample tweets below as evidence reflecting Artistic Interests, with one containing reference to poetry and the other to music:
Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality 10:9

Based on previous literature, certain evidence can be computed automatically. For example, Costa and McCrae have identified a person high on Intellect (another facet of Openness) often has a rich vocabulary [17]. Based on such findings, the richness of one's vocabulary can be computed automatically based on word use patterns, such as lexical density and diversity, in one's online communications (e.g., see Refs [42,50]). Based on this finding, a vocabulary richness score can be computed for each tweet and marketed as evidence related to trait Intellectual Curiosity.

Since it is impractical to identify each tweet as evidence relevant to one or more personality traits, we identify a Twitter user and associate him/her with one or more traits based on this person's known characteristics ("ground truth"). For example, we associate Lady Gaga (@ladygaga) with Artistic Interests given her profession. Likewise, a Stanford math professor (e.g., @joboaler) is related to trait Intellectual Curiosity, while a travel enthusiast (@wenphd) is associated with trait Adventurousness. Using this method, we identify and collect groups of Twitter users with shared, distinct characteristics (known groups). We then compare each known group's tweets with those of randomly selected users in our training set to extract a set of linguistic cues unique to the known group. Since much research shows that linguistic cues reflect personality traits (e.g., see Refs [1,35,47,51]), the extracted linguistic cues, including words, phrases, punctuations, and emoticons, are then considered potential evidence for reflecting the characteristics represented by each known group.

div.head: Step 2: Mining Evidence-Trait Relationships
div.p: To quantify the relationships between potential evidence (the linguistic cues identified in Step 1) and user traits, such as the Big 5 personality traits, we adopt a statistical inference approach, Item Response Theory, a widely used approach in modern psychometrics [19]. In particular, we model the desired traits as latent factors and potential evidence as observed items. The following formula can be used to estimate the relationships between evidence j and trait θ (trait score) for an individual i:
div.formula: X i j = μ j + λ j θ i + ε i j ; j = 1, N .(1)
div.p: Here, X is the observed data containing N pieces of evidence; μ j is the occurrence rate of evidence j; λ j measures the discriminative power of evidence j to trait θ ; and ɛ ij is the Gaussian distributed error uncorrelated with θ .
To estimate the parameters in Formula 1, we use the conditional distribution of X for trait θ :
div.formula: f (X j |θ i ) = 1 σ j √ 2π 1 X j (1 -X j ) e -1 2 [ ln( X j 1-X j )-μ σ j ] 2(2)
div.p: Here, μ is the expectation of μ after a logit transformation, and σ j 2 is the variance of residuals. The parameters can then be estimated using various algorithms, such as an Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm over the training data [21].

div.head: Step 3: Evidence-based Inference of Trait Scores
div.p: Given a user's text (e.g., Facebook posts, tweets, or chat text), the trained model can be applied to compute trait scores (Formula 1). Currently, we focus on inferring Big 5 personality factors and their 30 associated facets [23]. Any user-generated text (e.g., emails and blogs) can be used to infer a user's personality traits using our model. In all the field deployments described below, a user's chat text collected during an interview is used to infer the user's traits.

div.head: Validating Inferred User Traits
div.p: Similar to validating any other psychometric measures (e.g., see Refs [20,23]), we have evaluated our personality inference on two metrics: reliability (how consistent a measure is) and validity (how accurate a measure is). To measure the reliability of our model, we used our engine to analyze the tweets of 100,000 randomly sampled users to compute the Cronbach's α, a metric estimating the reliability of a psychometric test [16]. The results showed that our model requires about 1,000 words to achieve an acceptable reliability (α > = 0.8) for 19 out of 35 Big 5 personality traits. This means that given a certain amount of data evidence (e.g., 1,000 words), our engine can infer a person's traits reliably.

Following many other studies in evaluating machine-inferred personality traits (e.g., see Refs [1,35,47,51]), we also compared our inferred traits with personality traits measured using a traditional personality test. Like these works, we focused on reporting effect sizes, since such reporting facilitates the interpretation of the substantive as opposed to the statistical significance of a research result. It is considered a good practice when presenting empirical research findings [15].

To minimize inaccuracy or faking that may occur in a traditional personality test [108], we situated participants in a low-risk context. In particular, 475 student volunteers were recruited at a public university to take an IPIP-300 personality test 4 and also chat with our AI interviewer Kaya for about 1 hour. We then computed Pearson linear correlation coefficients as effect sizes to quantitatively measure the strength of two datasets: our machine inferred personality traits and personality scores by IPIP-300. Our results showed that these coefficients (r) range from -0.088 to 0.294 for 35 Big 5 personality traits. Table 1 lists top-13 traits with coefficients equal to or greater than 0.1 because these are considered significant [15]. It is worth noting that our coefficients appear stronger than that in other studies (e.g., see Refs [1,35]). For example, compared with our own previous work, the highest coefficient was 0.18 [35], while the current highest coefficient reached 0.29 (Table 1). Since both studies used the same IPIP-300 personality test, we attribute the differences to our respective personality inference engines. While our previous engine used LIWC word categories to predict Big 5 personality traits, our current engine uses much richer linguistic evidence to do so.

We also examined the negatively correlated traits, for example, Vulnerability, with the highest negative correlation. Due to social desirability biases, we are wondering how truthfully the students rated themselves on items, such as "I panic easily" or "I feel that I'm unable to deal with things," even though in a low-stake context like ours. In contrast, our AI agent did not ask any such questions during an interview but automatically inferred the trait.

To test the validity of our inference model, we further gathered empirical evidence. First, the hiring managers were able to quickly find suitable candidates based on the ranking of their inferred traits (e.g., Curiosity). The follow-up in-person interview assessments also showed certain consistency between human-assessed and the inferred traits. For example, an interviewee's Curiosity observed by a human interviewer matched her inferred curiosity. Second, as described in Section 8, Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality 10:11 our analysis results present certain evidence that corroborates the validity of inferred traits. For example, we found that Similar Personality and Extraversion are significant factors impacting users' perceptions of Kaya. Since Kaya is designed to be an extrovert, a user with a similar personality should also be an extrovert, which is consistent with the inferred Extraversion of this user. However, there is still much work needed to rigorously evaluate the validity of our personality inference model and such a task is non-trivial and often takes years of work [35]. This is because gathering ground-truth takes time and effort. For example, it takes time to validate whether a person is truly high on self-efficacy in the real world. One direction we are pursuing is to collect longitudinal data to examine how well the inferred traits predict users' real-world behavior, such as job performance or academic performance, especially in comparison with self-reported personality scores.

div.head: TOPIC-BASED CONVERSATION ENGINE
div.p: To power AI interviewers for practical uses, we have designed our conversation engine to meet three criteria. First, it must support diverse conversations and easy customizations of such conversations for a wide variety of interview situations, such as job interviews, patient inquiries, and customer surveys. Second, the engine must be easily extensible to accommodate new capabilities, e.g., extending an AI interviewer's ability to coach a user. Third, the engine must allow easy integration of third-party conversational technologies, e.g., Google Natural Language Processing (NLP) API.

With these design criteria in mind and inspired by cognitive architectures [53], we have developed a topic-based conversation engine that combines rule-based and algorithmic approaches to model and manage a conversation as a set of topics. In this approach, conversations can be easily customized to accommodate various interview situations through topic definitions. Moreover, conversational capabilities can be easily extended to incorporate third-party functions through topics.

div.head: Conversational Topics
div.p: We model a conversation as a set of topics, each of which defines a specific semantic theme of the conversation. Let us first define a conversational topic. Topic Representation. Semantically, a topic is similar to a discourse segment [13]. Figure 4 shows two example topics used in a job interview conversation: one soliciting initial information from a candidate (Figure 4(a)) and the other answering a candidate's questions regarding the position (Figure 4(b)). Each topic further consists of one or more semantic units, each of which handles a specific aspect of the topic.

The design of our semantic units is inspired by Artificial Intelligence Modeling Language (AIML), a language for programming chatbots [97], but improved for practical concerns (e.g., performance). Specifically, each semantic unit consists of a pair: a trigger (T) and a response (R). A trigger encodes one or more conditions under which a semantic unit may be activated during a conversation, while a response defines one or more corresponding agent actions. As shown in Figure 4(a), topic ask-user-intro has one semantic unit (T1-R1). Here, trigger T1 defines that the condition of asking a user for a self-introduction must be at the beginning of an interview. If this condition is met, the agent then asks the user to make a self-introduction (response R1). In Figure 4(b), topic answer-user-inquiry has two semantic units, one handling a user's inquiry on decision timeline (T2-R2) and the other on the number of candidates (T3-R3). These units define the respective conditions (triggers) and the corresponding agent responses.
Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality 10:13

For extensibility, both triggers and responses contain patterns of expressions and/or functions. For example, in R1, (ask-question) is a function and generates a text expression of a question. Figure 4(c) shows an example question, user-intro-q. Since a question definition often specifies only the heading of a question (see user-intro-q), function (ask-question) can transform a question heading into different expressions based on a conversational context. As described in Section 5.5, for example, it may phrase a question per Kaya's personality vs. that of Albert.

As shown in Figure 4(c), an agent may ask different types of questions during an interview. For example, question (user-intro-q) is an open-ended question to solicit a user's free-formed input, while (job-preference-q) is a choice-based question to ask a user's job preference. Choice-based questions are normally presented in a GUI form during an interview to simplify data processing.

Optionally, a semantic unit may be associated with a sub-topic that deepens a conversation on the topic. In Figure 4(a), (handle-user-response) is a sub-topic that handles a user's response to a question (?q). The definition of a sub-topic is the same as a regular topic, consisting of a set of semantic units. For example, in sub-topic (handle-user-response), semantic unit (T11-R11) states that if a user's answer (captured by ?input) is too short, the agent should ask for more information and then recursively processes the user's new input. In addition, semantic unit (T1N-R1N) defines that if a user's response is acceptable, the agent should move on and mark this topic done by calling the function (agenda-topic-done). As shown in this example, sub-topics may be recursively invoked (R11) to support virtually arbitrary levels of conversations.
Topic Properties. To manage various topics during a conversation, each topic is further associated with a set of properties.

Importance. Just like in a human-human conversation, not all topics are equally important. Currently, we support three types of topics, ranked by importance. There are agenda topics that must be activated during a conversation at a certain point in time. As described below, in an interview, an AI interviewer activates an agenda topic to pose interview questions and collect needed information from a user. There are fallback topics that may or may not be activated during a conversation. These topics are mostly used to help make conversational transitions or fill the gaps during a conversation. For example, assume that an agent has finished asking all the interview questions and there is still time left. One of the fallback topics may be activated to let the agent continue with a user. Error-handling topics are only activated if errors or unexpected situations occur during a conversation.
Structure. Since topics can be defined hierarchically with nested sub-topics, sub-topics can only be activated if their associated parent topics are activated.

Temporal Order. Similar to a human-human conversation, certain topics (e.g., asking a user to introduce himself) are discussed before others (e.g., the user's opinion on mobile phones). A partial temporal order may be specified among defined topics to control the topic order. Topics may not be ordered at all to support an arbitrary flow among them.

div.head: Configuring an AI Interviewer by Topics
div.p: Using topics and sub-topics mentioned above, we model an AI interviewer in three steps. First, we specify a set of interview questions, like those defined in Figure 4(c). Second, we define a set of topics and subtopics to pose interview questions and handle user responses to the questions. For example, in Figure 4(a)-4(b), topic (ask-user-intro) asks and handles a user's self-introduction, while topic (answer-job-inquiry) handles users' questions about the position. Third, we configure an AI interviewer based on the defined topics and questions. Figure 4(d) provides an example configuration. This configuration specifies four agenda topics, such as ask-user-intro and answer-job-inquiry, one activated after the other. In this configuration, the first three agenda topics have parameters, each of which represents an intended interview question. For example, topic ask-user-intro takes question user-intro-q (Figure 4(c)) as its parameter to ask a user to make a self-introduction. This parameterization enables these topics to be reused. In addition, there are two fallback topics, movie and sports, which may be activated in any order. This configuration also indicates the use of a special topic error-handling to handle various exceptions. A configuration can also define other properties of a REP, such as the name of an agent and the maximum duration allotted for an interview.

div.head: Running a REP by Agenda Topics and Topic Activation
div.p: Given a configured agent (Figure 4(d)), the conversation flow is managed through two parallel processes (Figure 5). The first process handle-agenda (Figure 5(a)) iterates through each defined agenda topic and activates one topic at a time, based on the specified temporal order (lines 1-5). Since a temporal order among these topics might be a partial order, it is possible that multiple agenda topics might be activated around the same time (lines 3-5). The activated agenda topics are then added to the activeTopics list to be processed (line 5).

To drive a conversation flow, the second process handle-active-topics (Figure 5(b)) examines all active topics and their associated properties, and decides which semantic unit under an active topic should be executed (lines 1-4). As described in Section 5.1, each topic contains one or more semantic units and each semantic unit contains a trigger that represents one or more conditions of a conversation. If a trigger is activated, the corresponding response defined in this semantic unit becomes a candidate for execution. For example, the state of a conversation may match trigger T1, while a user's input may match trigger T11 (Figure 4(a)). Accordingly, their corresponding responses (R1 and R11) are candidates for execution.

At a given time point of a conversation, however, one or more of the triggers may be matched. In such a case, the engine ranks them by their structure, importance, and temporal order, as mentioned in Section 5.1 (line 3, Figure 5(b)). Specifically, it ranks an agenda topic or its subtopic the highest by their temporal order, if any, followed by fallback and error-handling topics. This ranking allows a conversation to go deeper and guarantees that all agenda topics be discussed. By the ranking, the top-ranked semantic unit is then executed. The agent will then respond accordingly as defined by the semantic unit (e.g., R11). Depending on the definition of a response, the conversation may go deeper into a subtopic (e.g., R11 for topic ask-user-intro) or ends the current agenda topic (e.g., R1N). If the current agenda topic is ended, it is then removed from the agenda and the activeTopics list.

Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality 10:15 A conversation continues if there are still agenda topics to be processed (line 1, Figure 5(a)). Unless the conversation is explicitly terminated by one of the agenda topics, the conversation will still go on even after all agenda topics are done. This is because the activeTopics always include fallback topics, which can be activated by a user's input (Figure 5(b)), e.g., in a post-interview conversation.

div.head: Pattern-Based User Input Interpretation
div.p: Accurately interpreting a user's input is one of the biggest challenges in building a conversational system. Although our agent infers a user's traits based on observed linguistic cues (Formula 1) without the need to understand every user input precisely, it still must understand a user's input adequately to drive the interview process. To support the real-world use of an AI interviewer, we adopt a pattern-based approach to user input interpretation, since it has shown its effectiveness in many conversational systems [97,100]. Each pattern is defined by a composition of tokens, strings, or regular expressions, which are recognized as states in a finite-state machine (FSM). We chose to use FSM to process users' natural language input for two reasons. First, we do not have interview data to train a language model. We must bootstrap our system by coding patterns of expressions (rules) to match potential user input. Second, FSM can capture diverse language patterns and prior work demonstrates its effectiveness in processing user input in conversation systems [67].

As detailed in Ref. [67], each pattern defined in a trigger (e.g., T2 and T3, Figure 4(b)) can be represented by an FSM. For generalization purposes, where a pattern can match with many input variants, our engine automatically lemmatizes tokens and inserts wildcards. For example, the pattern [how many apply] defined in trigger T3 (Figure 4(b)) can match a wide variety of user inquiring expressions regarding the number of candidates, such as "how many candidates have applied for the job" or "how many applied for the position."

It is worth pointing out that the main goal of our AI interviewers is to ask interview questions and obtain user responses. This is very different from many conversational systems of which the main goal is to perform a specific task (e.g., scheduling an appointment). In an interview context, if an agent fails to comprehend a user's response or answer a user's question, it can be guided to continue the conversation gracefully (e.g., skipping the current interview question).

Patterns are compiled into optimized FSMs by minimizing the number of states [67]. The FSM compiler itself is optimized by using several novel pattern rewriting techniques, such as recursively factoring out common prefixes and suffixes, retracting a large list of alternatives into a single special token, and eliminating duplicated patterns. As a result, hundreds of thousands of complex patterns can be compiled within seconds. Our current FSM runtime can process more than 100 million user input tokens per second on a mid-tier Macbook Pro Laptop.

div.head: Template-Based System Utterance Generation
div.p: Currently, we use a template-based approach to generate an agent's utterances during a conversation. To make an agent sound natural, an utterance template may include multiple alternatives. For example, a template that allows an agent to utter positive confirmations may include options, such as "Great job" and "Well done." Moreover, a template may consist of multiple segments. For example, here is a template that contains two segments, one explaining why the asking, while the other states the actual question: ask-fav-movie-template = <why-ask><question>. Here <why-ask> may contain a set of alternatives: {:option1 "I love magic so my favorite movie is . . . " :personality :cheerful} {:option2 "Psychology studies show that . . . " :personality :serious}

div.head: Effective Inquiring
div.p: Affective strategy [36]; Positive politeness [12] Cognitive strategy [36]; Negative politeness [12] Example: "You are so

div.head: Linguistic Style
div.p: Questions, suggestions, affective expressions [9,36,104] Assertions, projective statements, terse expressions [36,72,104] Examples: "Thank you so much for your input! " "Could you say a bit more?"
Examples: "Thanks." "Please tell me more."

As shown above, these alternatives are associated with a personality tag, which allows agent utterances to be customized to suit their personality. For example, option 1 is used by cheerful Kaya to phrase the question, while option 2 for serious Albert. Whenever suitable, utterance segments are tagged with different descriptors, such as a personality descriptor or style descriptor (e.g., affective vs. cognitive expressions, see more in Section 6.1). At runtime, the conversation engine selects suitable utterances by such descriptors to match the personality or style of an agent.

div.head: DESIGN OF A VIRTUAL INTERVIEWER
div.p: To answer our research questions, we developed two AI interviewers, each with a distinct personality that is associated with effective human interviewers [45,104].

div.head: Two Virtual Personas
div.p: Existing studies suggest two types of effective human interviewers: one with a warm, cheerful personality, effective at building rapport with interviewees, and the other with a serious, assertive personality, effective at requesting cooperation from interviewees [45,104]. We thus designed and built two virtual personas. Table 2 summarizes the two AI interviewers and their matched behavior.
Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality 10:17

Appearance. Since people often associate one's appearance with a particular personality [48,77,101], we created two static profile images, each representing a distinct persona. In particular, Kaya takes the form of a cheerful female, while Albert is a serious-looking male (Table 2). Our gender assignment is based on psychology studies, which show women in general are warmer and more sensitive in their personality, while men are more reserved and dominant [32,99].

Conversational Behavior. In addition to appearance, an agent's conversational behavior exhibits its personality [11]. Specifically, we unveil the personality of an AI interviewer through four types of conversational behavior associated with an interview task.

Effective Inquiring. Clinical studies show that interviewers can use different techniques to effectively draw out information from interviewees. For example, an affective strategy helps an interviewer establish rapport with an interviewee, which then allows the interviewee to open up and act authentically [36]. On the other hand, negative politeness may be used to preserve the emotional distance between an interviewer and an interviewee, minimizing imposition on the interviewee [12]. Since the use of particular strategies or techniques reveals an interviewer's personality, we match our virtual personas with different inquiring strategies or techniques. Specifically, aligning with her warm and cheerful personality, Kaya uses an affective strategy and positive politeness in a conversation, while Albert uses a cognitive strategy and negative politeness to reveal his reserved and serious personality. Effective Influencing. Besides eliciting information, an interviewer may also want to influence interviewees (e.g., encouraging them to think outside the box) [72]. To achieve this goal, we introduce influence operators [11] to help virtual interviewers effectively guide interviewees to perform their best. To exhibit an interviewer's personality, we assign different influence operators: Kaya uses empathetic and cooperative language, while Albert's language is reassuring and forgiving.
See expression examples used by Kaya and Albert, respectively, in Table 2.

Small Talk. While small talk helps make a conversation more engaging [11], it may also block honest interaction [37]. To match their personalities, Kaya uses small talk to build rapport and show her friendly side, while Albert rarely chitchats to reflect his serious persona. In our current implementation, small talk is incorporated as part of an interview question or a response to a user's input. See the contrasting sample expressions used by Kaya and Albert in Table 2.

Linguistic Style. Since one's linguistic style unveils one's personality [74,81], we incorporate matching linguistic cues (e.g., words, phases, and punctuations) into our AI interviewers' utterances. These linguistic cues are selected based on previous studies [47,49,104] and our own findings that establish the relationships between various linguistic cues and personality traits (Formula 1). For example, Kaya frequently uses first-person, affective expressions ("I love romantic movies as they make me cry."), emoticons, and exclamations. In contrast, Albert uses third-person declarative, projective statements ("It makes sense.") or abbreviated replies ("Understood."). Moreover, Kaya uses questions and suggestions to show her friendliness, while Albert uses assertions and demands to display his seriousness.

As mentioned in Section 5.5, we use a template-based approach to agent utterance generation. We have implemented a set of templates to cover common conversational acts, such as greeting and acknowledging [83]. To reflect the personality of an AI interviewer, we have created alternative expressions within a template based on various strategies mentioned above and associate each with a corresponding personality descriptor (see Section 5.5). For example, an acknowledging template contains thank-you expressions corresponding to different personalities (e.g., examples in the last row of Table 2). During runtime, our system selects the ones that match the given personality of an AI interviewer.

div.head: Interview Questions
div.p: To create a customized AI interviewer, typically an organization first provides us with a set of interview questions pertinent to their context, such as inquiring about a job candidate's interests and skills related to a position in a job interview or asking a student's experience with a class in an educational setting. We put in additional remarks and questions to: (1) make the interview flow more naturally, (2) measure candidates' willingness to confide in and listen to a virtual interviewer, and (3) solicit candidates' perception and feedback of the AI interviewer. Although each field deployment consisted of very different interview questions, each interview flow is similar with five parts shown below.

(I) Introduction. The first part includes a set of open-ended questions, helping an agent build rapport with a user. It typically starts by asking the user to make a self-introduction, and then chats with the user to collect additional information, such as the user's hobbies, favorite movie, and role model. (II) Impression Management Questionnaire. The second part includes a 20-item impression management (IM) scale [34] to measure how much one inflates his/her own image by exaggerating desirable responses especially in a high-stakes situation like a job interview. We also want to use this measure to examine an interviewee's willingness to be true to him/herself during an interview. (III) Opinion Questions. This part normally includes a set of open-ended questions that solicited a user's input or opinions on various subjects related to a specific interview situation. Some of these questions were controversial in nature, aiming at measuring a user's willingness to confide in and listen to an agent (see more below). (IV) About You. This part includes a set of questions, asking a user more information about herself, such as her job preferences, skills and interests, and strengths and weaknesses. The agent often shares and discusses its analysis of a user, such as her personality traits, top strength, and top weakness. The agent may also suggest certain actions, which were meant to measure users' willingness to listen to the agent (see more below). (V) Post Interview Survey. This last part collects demographics from users and their rating of the REP on several aspects, from personality to usability (see more below).

Measuring Users' Willingness to Confide in an Agent. Drawing out authentic information from interviewees is paramount to any successful interview, since such information helps both interviewers and interviewees better assess real-life situations (e.g., the fitness of a candidate for a particular job) [72]. However, due to social desirability biases-especially in high-stakes situations like job interviews-interviewees may not be completely truthful [73,106]. While studies show that users are more willing to confide in machines [59], we want to further understand how the personality of an agent and the personality of a person affect one's willingness to confide in the agent, especially in high-stakes situations.

To answer our first research question, we assess one's willingness to confide in a an agent by their willingness to share sensitive information with others, such as a hiring manager. In particular, we measure such willingness through two sets of measures in an interview: the Impression Management (IM) scale, and asking the users to take actions to reveal and share sensitive information about themselves or their opinions on controversial topics with a third party, e.g., a hiring manager.
Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality 10:19
div.formula: B j = C F j × sAction j S j = rating j × j Share Opinions (j = 1, K ) Share Action (j = 1, M ) C F j = ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ 1, High 2, Med 3, Low sAction j = 0, don't share 1, share rating j = ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ 3, disagree 2, not sure 1, agree act j = 1, share REP's 0, share mine (a) Willingness to confide: W C = A + K j =1 B j (b) Willingness to listen: W L = N i =1 C i + M j =1 S j
div.p: The IM scale [73], also known as a "lie" or social desirability scale, is designed to detect how users consciously favor themselves to impress others. A user rates oneself using a 7-point Likert scale on each of 20 statements, such as "I have never driven over a speed limit." If a user rates oneself on the scale of 6 or 7 on this statement to indicate that s/he has never driven over speed limit, it is most likely that s/he consciously inflates oneself since the statement describes an extreme situation. In this case, s/he receives one point. After going through twenty statements, a user receives an accumulated total score. The higher the score, the more inflation there is, and thus, the less willing one is to confide in another with honest ratings [73].

In addition to the IM scale, we designed user actions to measure one's willingness to confide in an agent. In our interview context, each action is related to sharing certain sensitive information or an opinion on a controversial subject with a third party who can influence an interviewee's life (e.g., a hiring manager or an academic advisor).

Table 3(a) provides two example actions used in our field deployments. The first one is to share a user's biggest weakness. The agent asks a user about her biggest weakness before showing its inferred top weakness for the user. The agent then asks the user to rate the inferred weakness by a 3-point rating (Table 3(a)). Heuristically, this rating measures the "sensitivity" of the information to be shared. If a user disagrees with the system-suggested weakness, this weakness information might be more sensitive and a user might feel more risky to share such a weakness with someone who has influences. As part of the action, the user must choose one of three actions (sAction in Table 3(a)). The user's rating and choice of action are then used to compute the user's willingness to confide in an agent (A in Table 3(a)). By this measure, a user is most willing to confide in the agent if she shares her weakness suggested by the agent, even if she disagrees with its analysis.

Another example of a sharing action is to solicit a user's opinion on a controversial subject (e.g., "What important truth do very few people agree with you on?"). In our field deployments, our clients wanted to use such questions to assess an interviewee's soft skills from sources like Ref. [89]. On a controversial subject, the agent first asks a user's opinion and then probes further by eliciting a rationale or offering counter viewpoints. The agent then asks the user's confidence in her opinion (CF in Table 3(a)) before asking her action (sAction in Table 3(a)). Per the user's reported confidence and choice of action, the willingness to confide in is then computed (Table 3

div.head: (a)).
div.p: As seen from the example actions above, we designed user actions to measure one's willingness to confide at multiple scales instead of as a binary value (sharing vs. no sharing). Moreover, we design the actions to measure the "sensitivity" of the information to be shared. The less confidence a user has in the information, the more sensitive the information is. By our measure, a user is most willing to confide in an agent if she shares the most "sensitive" information with a third party.

Our rationale is that people always want to show their best qualities, especially in a high-stakes situation like a job interview. When they have an option not to share something they are uncertain of, they could hold back without risking exposure of their weaknesses unless they are willing to confide in an agent despite the risks.

The sharing actions described above are just examples used in our field deployments. Such actions may be adapted for a specific interview situation by the same design principles mentioned above. For example, one of our real-world deployments is to interview university students to find out how their personality may be related to their academic interests and performance. Instead of asking a student's willingness to share his/her top weakness, the question is revised to ask the candidate's willingness to share with his/her academic advisor who would give him/her the worst reference. Although the questions may be different, the goal is the same: it is to measure a user's willingness to confide in by sharing sensitive information. When designing such actions, we should also carefully balance between being able to distinguish a user's behavior and the required user cognitive effort, especially when an interview is involved and long. This is also why we use a simple 3-point scale to distinguish a user's behavior (Table 3).

Measuring Users' Willingness to Listen to an Agent. In addition to eliciting authentic responses from interviewees, an interviewer should also effectively guide the interviewees and help them reveal their best qualities (e.g., demonstrating thoughtfulness). However, users may not always be willing to listen to machines [77,78]. To answer our second research question and find out what might affect users' willingness to listen to an agent, we designed a set of user actions using the similar principles described above to measure one's willingness to listen to an agent. Table 3(b) shows two sample actions and their measures.

Again, such user actions may be adapted for different interview situations. Here, we give several example actions used in our field deployments to demonstrate how we measure one's willingness to listen. In one such action, willingness to listen is measured by a user's click-through after an agent asks the user to read online articles related to the current interview topic by clicking on the articles' URLs.

Another type of action is related to persuading a user to share a piece of agent-suggested information. Similar to the classic Desert Survival Problem that is used to test the power of persuasion [78], this type of action that tests one's willingness to listen has four steps. The agent first asks a user's input on a specific subject (e.g., her top skill) before offering a suggestion, which is often different from the user's input. The agent then asks the user to rate its suggestion (rating in Table 3(b)) before persuading her to share its suggestion, as opposed to the self-reported one, with a third party, who can often influence the user's real life. In such an action, willingness to listen is measured by how strongly a user disagrees with an agent's suggestion and the user's final choice of action.

Measuring Users' Perceptions of an Agent. Based on previous studies on anthropomorphic interfaces [54,77,86,87], we have designed four sets of Likert-scale questions to measure users' perceptions of an AI interviewer. The first set asks users' perceived trustworthiness of an agent, since such perceptions may be directly related to their willingness to confide in and listen to the agent. To validate the effectiveness of our personality manipulation (i.e., whether users have perceived an agent's given personality), the second set asks users' perceptions of an agent's personality from multiple aspects, such as perceived characteristics (e.g., how cheerful or reserved an agent is), role similarity (i.e., how an agent is similar to a friend or a counselor), and personality similarity (i.e., how similar a user's personality is to an agent's). The third set asks a user to rate the quality of an agent from several aspects (e.g., likeability and insightfulness). The last set solicits a user's feedback on an agent's usability (i.e., how enjoyable it is) [78].
Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality 10:21

div.head: FIELD DEPLOYMENTS
div.p: As described in Section 6, we have designed two distinct interviewer personas, warm and cheerful Kaya and serious and assertive Albert, each of which aims at achieving a particular interview goal that we study. Specifically, based on previous findings [45,106], Kaya would be better at establishing rapport with users and encourages users to confide in this agent, while Albert would be better at demanding cooperation and encourages users to listen to this agent. In addition, we have carefully designed a set of interactions that users must perform during an interview so that we can measure their behavior with each AI interviewer persona.

Kaya and Albert were used in a number of real-world deployments. For the purpose of answering our research questions, we present four relevant deployments, involving a total of 1,280 interviewees. Among these four deployments, two of them were conducted in high-stakes situations for real job interviews, while the other two were done in lower-stakes situations for educational purposes. Across all four deployments, each user spent well over an hour with an agent and contributed about 1,600 words on average.

div.head: Interviewing Entry-Level Job Applicants (Deployment I)
div.p: In this field deployment, we deployed both Kaya and Albert to aid a firm in hiring an entry-level associate. The firm received about 800 applications and notified all the applicants to expect an email invitation of a virtual interview opportunity and encouraged them to use this opportunity to showcase their unique characteristics. Half of the candidates were invited to interview with Kaya, and the other half to interview with Albert. Each email invitation contained an individualized URL to start the interview at our website. Each interview contained five parts (Section 6.2) and questions in Part I (Introduction) and Part III (Opinion Questions) were customized by the hiring manager to suit the hiring context.

The process lasted about three weeks, during which 157 applicants completed their virtual interviews with Kaya, 159 completed theirs with Albert, and 59 people started but did not finish their interviews. Among the 157 users with Kaya, there were 130 (83%) male and 27 female (17%); among the 159 users with Albert, there were 125 (79%) male and 33 (21%) female. Users' ages ranged from 18 to over 50, and 90% of them were between 18 to 35 years old. On average, each user spent about 75 minutes interviewing with Kaya or Albert.

div.head: Interviewing Summer Internship Applicants (Deployment II)
div.p: Similar to Deployment I, this field deployment helped a high-tech firm interview their summer internship applicants. Because all their applicants are university students, the firm believed that Kaya in a younger, warmer persona would better engage with the student population than Albert would and decided to use only Kaya for all the virtual interviews. In this case, each internship applicant first submitted an application via email. S/he then received an automatic email response that contains a URL where the applicant could sign up and complete an interview with Kaya before a deadline.

Similar to Deployment I, each interview contained five parts (Section 6.2) with questions customized to suit the hiring context. By the deadline, a total of 454 students signed up, 307 students started their virtual interview, and 290 of them completed theirs. Among those who completed, ages ranged between 18-35, 89 (31%) of them were female, 201 (69%) were male, and 186 (64%) were international students. On average, each applicant spent about 1.5 hours with Kaya.

div.head: Interviewing Students for Team Experience and Preferences (Deployment III)
div.p: Unlike the two deployments described above, this deployment was conducted by a professor in a big public university to: (1) gather information from the students in his class about their team project experience and preferences, and (2) infer the students' personality traits. The purpose was to help students find better teammates in class projects. For the same reason as described above, Kaya was chosen as the AI interviewer for the student population. Like the interviews in Deployments I & II, each interview also contained five parts (Section 6.2) but with questions customized to suit the context. For example, in Part III (Opinions), Kaya asked each student a series of team-related questions designed by the professor, e.g., "What have you learned from the past team experience?" There were 201 students in the class, all of whom completed an interview with Kaya as one of their class assignments. Since eight (8) students did not submit their consent form, we excluded their data from our analysis. Among the 193 students, all of them between 18-25 years old, 145 (75%) were male, 48 (25%) were female, and 70 (36%) were international students. On average, each user spent about 90 minutes interviewing with Kaya.

div.head: Interviewing Students for Assessing Student Personality Traits (Deployment IV)
div.p: The fourth deployment was also conducted in another big public university. It aimed at using interviewers to infer students' personality traits and investigate how the inferred traits may be related to the students' academic performance. Again, Kaya was chosen as the interviewer for the student population. Likewise, Kaya conducted each interview in five parts (Section 6.2) with customized questions. For example, for opinion questions (Part III), Kaya asked each student a series of school-related questions, such as "What's your favorite class?"

In this deployment, each student volunteer received extra course credits upon the completion of an interview with Kaya. A total of 473 students completed an interview with Kaya, all between 18-25 years old. Among the students, 351 (74%) were female, 122 (26%) were male, and 20 (6%) were international students. On average, each student spent around an hour with Kaya.

div.head: RESULTS
div.p: We first present an overview of the results and then present our analysis answering our three research questions.

div.head: Overview of Results
div.p: In Deployment 1, after each interview, we asked users to rate their perception of the REP's personality traits (on a scale of 1-5). The top three rated personality traits for Kaya were calm (mean = 3.89, std = 1.04), cheerful (mean = 3.875, std = 1.01), and warm (mean = 3.82, std = 1.09), and for Albert, calm (mean = 4.15, std = 0.88), rational (mean = 3.96, std = 0.93), and assertive (mean = 3.58, std = 0.94). Except for the highly rated calm for Kaya, users' perceptions matched with the intended personality of Kaya and Albert (Table 2). We attributed Kaya's perceived calmness to her role as a job interviewer. In Deployments II, III, and IV, instead of rating Kaya's personality traits, each interviewee was asked to describe Kaya's personality in three keywords. The idea was to learn what descriptors users would use.

We collected the keywords and computed their frequencies. Figure 6 shows the top-10 most frequently cited keywords from the three deployments. As shown, the interviewees' descriptions about Kaya across deployments were consistent: the most mentioned words were friendly, kind, and nice, which matched with our persona design of Kaya. In Deployment III, robotic was also used frequently to describe Kaya. As shown below in Table 4, users in this deployment also rated Kaya the lowest across almost all the dimensions. We were wondering whether the user reaction had something to do with the interview context: in this deployment, the students were required to chat with Kaya by their professor as one of their homework assignments, while users in other deployments opted in to chat with Kaya.
Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality 10:23 Fig. 6. Top-10 words most frequently used by users to describe Kaya's personality. Table 4. Results of User Ratings on REP (*p<.05)
The Highest Rating in Each Rating (row) Is Highlighted in Yellow, While the Second Highest Rating Is Highlighted in Gray.

Table 4 summarizes various user ratings for all the four deployments. In Deployment I, where both Albert and Kaya were used, an independent samples t-test showed no significant differences in most of user ratings between the two agents except that Kaya was rated to be significantly more like a friend than Albert t(307) = 2.54, p < .01. Each agent was also rated on three trust measures (integrity, competence, and benevolence) [64], which were combined additively to create an index measure called Trust. As shown in Table 4 (the last row), users trusted Albert more than Kaya, and an independent samples t-test showed a trend: t(314) = 1.88, p < .06. Across all four deployments, it is interesting to observe that job interviewees rated their impression of an agent higher than university students across almost all the dimensions. This might be because they considered the AI interview part of their application process and were more engaged with and positive about the agent. Moreover, summer internship applicants in Deployment II were more positive about Kaya than the job applicants in Deployment I. This might be because most of the intern candidates were Computer Science majors and were more familiar with and valued more the concept of AI agents.

Furthermore, in Deployments II, III, and IV, users were also asked to indicate their communication preference with an agent. Among the 964 users who completed an interview in these three deployments, 800 (83%) preferred the current text-based chat, while 164 (17%) would have preferred a voice-based conversation with an agent.

div.head: R1: Effects of Agent Personality on Users' Willingness to Confide In
div.p: Our first research question is to examine the effects of agent personality on users' willingness to confide in an agent. Since only Deployment I used two different agents, our analysis below analyzed the data from Deployment I.
As mentioned earlier, we measured one's willingness to confide in an agent from two aspects: the IM Scale [73] and a set of actions measured by an index variable Willingness to Confide (Table 3(a)).

By the IM Scale, users were less likely to want to impress Albert (mean = 12.68, sd = 3.48) than Kaya (mean = 12.93, sd = 3.44), although this difference was not significant. Using the IM scale as a dependent variable, we ran a General Linear Model (GLM) with three independent variables5 : Trust (user perceived trustworthiness of an agent), Similar Personality (how similar users felt the agent's personality was to their own), and Agent (distinguishing Kaya from Albert), controlling for user's Gender. The result showed Trust was the only significant factor: F(1,302) = 5.65, p < .02, Coeff = .59. This implies that the more the users trust an agent, the more likely they want to consciously impress the agent. This finding seems consistent with the theory that people apply the same social rules to computers as they apply to humans [78]. In other words, people often want to impress someone whom they trust (e.g., parents and spouses).

With Willingness to Confide as a dependent variable, we ran a GLM with the same three independent variables: Trust, Similar Personality, and Agent, also controlling for Gender. It showed that Agent was significant: F(1, 302) = 5.38, p < .02, Coeff = .46. This implies that users are more willing to confide in Albert and they are more willing to do so if they trust the agent more. Gender was insignificant.

Our results show that users are more honest with (per the IM score) and more willing to confide in Albert. Initially, we hypothesized that users would be more willing to confide in an agent like Kaya who should be better at building rapport based on previous work (e.g., see Ref. [9]). However, our results are the opposite.

div.head: R2: Effects of Agent Personality on Users' Willingness to Listen
div.p: Our second research question is to examine the effects of an agent personality on users' willingness to listen to an agent. Since only Deployment I used two agents, the analysis used the data only from Deployment I.

Using an additive index of users' actions, Willingness to Listen (Table 3(b)) as the dependent variable, we ran a GLM over the same independent variables: Trust, Similar Personality, and Agent, controlling for Gender. It showed that Agent was significant: F(1, 302) = 4.15, p <. 04, Coeff = .39. This result showed that users are more willing to listen to Albert, an agent with a reserved, assertive personality. However, since Similar Personality was not significant (p < .09), users may not necessarily be willing to listen to an agent who possesses a similar personality. We thus are unable to confirm previous findings [78,87].

div.head: R3: Effects of Interview Context and User Individual Differences on User Behavior
div.p: To answer our third research question, we examined whether and how the context of a virtual interview and users' individual differences, such as gender and personality traits inferred from the interview, influence their perception of an agent as well as their behavior with an agent. We

Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality 10:25 analyzed two datasets: (1) the Kaya dataset that consisted of Kaya interviews in all the four deployments, and (2) the Albert dataset in Deployment I. As shown below, we examined the effects of a set of independent variables on user perception and behavior with Kaya and Albert, respectively.

Interview Context (high-stakes vs. low-stakes). Numerous studies show that context (e.g., leisure vs. work) affects users' perception of virtual agents (e.g., see Refs [68,86]). In addition, research shows that interview context influences a user's willingness to confide in or volunteer truthful information to a computer (e.g., see Refs [27,73,108]). For example, a person is less likely to inflate oneself or lie in a low-stakes context [73].
