Since our goal is to create effective agents who can elicit authentic information from users in any context, we wanted to examine how an interview context might influence users' perception of and behavior with an agent.

Our four deployments happened to be situated in two different contexts: real-world job interviews and surveys with university students. The first context is a high-stakes context as a job was at stake based on the interview. The second context is low-stakes, where the students had little at stake to impress or to deceive the agent in order to increase their stature. We thus examined how these two contexts affect a user's perceptions of and behavior with an agent.

div.head: Individual Differences.
div.p: As shown in existing work, individual differences, such as gender and cultural background, affect one's perceptions of and behavior with virtual agents. In our analysis, we used four measures of individual differences.

Similar Personality. Previous research suggests that people who view an agent's personality similar to theirs should rate the agent higher [69]. We wanted to know whether a higher score on this measure would indicate a higher trust, higher agent quality, or higher enjoyment rating of an agent. Culture. Cultures influence people's perceptions of and behavior with virtual agents [26]. The interviewees involved in our field deployments had different cultural backgrounds. For example, 64% of job applicants for the summer internship positions were international students. We were curious about whether their background would impact their perceptions of or behavior with a REP. For this analysis, one's cultural background was coarsely determined by one's native language since each user was asked of his/her native language during their interview. Based on the data collected, each user was assigned with one of two "culture" labels: "western culture" (associated with native languages such as English and Spanish) and "eastern culture" (associated with native languages such as Chinese or Indian). Gender. We controlled for Gender since previous research indicates that females and males may perceive and respond to an agent differently [86]. Inferred Personality Traits. We expected that users' personality traits, inferred from their text during an interview, would affect their perceptions of and behavior with an agent. We performed a factor analysis on the 35 inferred Big 5 personality traits using a Varimax rotation with a Kaiser normalization for the Kaya and Albert datasets, respectively. For the Kaya dataset, a scree plot 6 revealed that seven factors should be used, accounting for 51.56% of the variance (Table 5(a)). For Albert, a scree plot revealed seven factors accounting for 51.83% of the variance (Table 5(b)). -Perceived Trust. As mentioned before, the Trust index measures users' perceived trust in an agent by additively combining their 5-point Likert scale ratings on an agent from three aspects: benevolence, integrity, and competence. -Perceived Agent Quality. Each interviewee was asked to rate an agent on a 5-point Likert scale from four aspects: how insightful, helpful, likeable, and interesting the agent was perceived. Since all the four metrics were significantly correlated, we created an additive index of these measures called Agent Quality Rating to measure a user's perceived agent quality. -Perceived Enjoyment. Each interviewee was asked to rate how much they enjoyed chatting with an agent on a 5-point Likert-scale. We use this Enjoyment Rating to measure one's perceived enjoyment.

div.head: Effect of Interview Context and Individual
div.p: We examined the effects of interview context and individual differences on each of these three variables. To do so, each of these three variables was entered in a stepwise regression model 7 as a dependent variable with interview context and individual difference measures described above as independent variables. We used forward selection stepwise regression to find the best predictive model. All the results are summarized in Table 6. The independent variables entered for the Kaya model are different from those entered for the Albert model. This is because the Albert dataset was collected under only one context (Deployment I for job interview) and did not have users' cultural background information. On modeling users' perceived trust for Kaya, our stepwise regression results found that Similar Personality and personality factors 1 (Extroversion and Cheerfulness) and 7 (Excitement-Seeking) significantly influenced one's perceived trust in Kaya. The more similar the personality, the more extroverted and cheerful (like Kaya), and the less one seeks excitement, the more trust one has in Kaya. Note that our users' personality traits are automatically inferred. This finding also validated our trait inference: users who have a personality similar to Kaya are indeed extroverted and cheerful as expected.

On the other hand, on modeling users' perceived trust in Albert, we found that Similar Personality and personality factor 4 were significant. The less open (more conservative) they were, the more they trusted Albert. This is very plausible due to Albert's personality since users might perceive Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality 10:27 Albert as being conservative, and that they assess their personalities (conservative) as being more similar to Albert. In this sense, our trait inference engine again correctly identified those with a more conservative characteristic. On modeling users' perceived agent quality, for both Kaya and Albert, we found that only Similar Personality was a significant factor. In other words, users who felt having a personality similar to an agent rated the agent higher on its quality.

On modeling users' perceived enjoyment, again for both Kaya and Albert, the results showed that Similar Personality was significant. In other words, if one has a personality similar to an agent, the person would enjoy chatting with the agent more. For Kaya, Interview Context was also significant. Users might have invested more in interacting with an agent in a high-stakes context, where they could potentially land a job.

div.head: Interview Context and Individual Differences on User
div.p: Behavior with an Agent. We next analyzed how interview context and individual differences influence users' behavior with an agent. To address our research questions, we were interested in two types of user behavior: (1) willingness to confide (IM scale as part of it) and (2) willingness to listen. To do so, we entered each measure as a dependent variable in a stepwise regression with interview context and individual differences as independent variables. Table 7 summarizes the results.

Willingness to confide. For Kaya, Interview Context and personality factors 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, and 7 (Table 5(a)) significantly impacted users' willingness to confide in Kaya. In particular, in a highstakes context, open-minded and cooperative people were more likely to confide in Kaya. On the other hand, in such a context, more extroverted, excitement-seeking, anxious, and vulnerable people are less likely to confide in Kaya. It is worth noting that our results are consistent with the findings in social science studies, where open-minded, agreeable (cooperative) people are more willing to trust strangers [29]. Considering Kaya a friendly stranger, users apply the same social rules to computers as found in many studies [68]. However, such trust did not show up in a lowstakes context. One reason might be that people were less engaged with an agent in that context. For Albert, no significant factors were found, which might be due to inadequate data (159 users).

IM Scale. As explained in Section 6.2, as part of the "willingness to confide" measure, the IM scale measures one's tendency to inflate oneself by consciously lying during a self-evaluation and is often influenced by context [73] and individual differences [94]. On the surface, the IM scores were quite different under the two contexts of our deployments. In Deployments I and II for job interviews (high stakes), IM scores measured a mean = 12.64, sd = 3.44, while in Deployments III and IV in a university setting (lower stakes), they measured a mean = 8.48, sd = 3.37. Our stepwise regression showed that Gender, Interview Context, and personality factors 1 and 4 (Table 5(a)) significantly impact IM scores. In particular, in a high-stakes context, conscientious males tended to inflate their image much more than extroverted females. Our finding is consistent with previous results, which show that people who have high self-control (associated with Conscientiousness) score higher on the IM scale [94]. For Albert, only personality factor 2 (Table 5(b)) was significant, suggesting that emotionally more stable people inflated their image more.

Willingness to listen. Similar Personality and personality factor 1 (Extroversion and Cheerfulness) significantly affected users' willingness to listen to Kaya. For Albert, however, no factors were significant. This implies that extroverted, cheerful users are more willing to listen to an agent Trusting Virtual Agents: The Effect of Personality 10:29 with a similar personality. Since Kaya was given a cheerful persona, the agreement between users' self-assessment (Similar Personality to Kaya) with their system-inferred traits (factor 1) seems to be validating the inferred personality traits. Moreover, our findings are consistent with other findings: users similar to an agent are more willing to cooperate with the agent [68,86,87].

div.head: SUMMARY OF FINDINGS AND DISCUSSION
div.p: Here, we summarize our findings and discuss the limitations in our current work, along with ongoing research, including design implications on building hyper-personalized intelligent agents based on automatically inferred user traits.

div.head: Findings and Implications
div.p: We summarize three key findings and state their implications on designing effective virtual interviewers.

Practical Values of AI Interviewers. Our field deployments demonstrated several practical values of AI interviewers. It makes a recruiting process more efficient, objective, and inclusive. In Deployment I, out of 800 applicants with half of them who simply ignored the interview invite and 59 who did not finish their interview, the hiring manager was able to quickly identify 12 quality candidates based on several inferred characteristics (e.g., Responsible and Action-Oriented) out of the 316 who completed their virtual interview. He also commented that a few of the 12 would have gone unnoticed by their resumes alone.

In Deployment II, 454 applicants signed up for an interview with Kaya, 307 started an interview, and 290 completed theirs. The hiring manager spent about 2 hours to select 60 candidates who ranked high on several dimensions (e.g., Self-Discipline and Detail-Oriented) and followed up with them in a technical interview to test their algorithmic and programming skills. Among the 60 candidates, 16 scored Excellent on a 4-level scale (Weak, Ok, Good, and Excellent). These results were impressive compared with a similar intern hiring process without the aid of an agent. In that process, the same hiring manager spent a couple of weeks to screen the resumes of over 400 applicants and selected 60 for the follow-up technical interview. Among the 60 students, only 6 of them were scored Excellent. In addition, the candidates selected based on their traits inferred from their virtual interview were much more diverse, including students from many different universities. Although we could not build a technical competence prediction model using the inferred personality traits for the small sample set (N = 60), just the amount of screening time saved and the diversity of the candidates discovered through the AI interviews make the agents quite valuable for hiring managers.

Furthermore, users appear to act authentically around an AI interviewer to reveal their true character even in a high-stakes situation. For example, one job applicant told Albert that his question was dumb, while another told Kaya to "drink warm water" after Kaya got stuck and said "I just had a brain freeze" when recovering from an error. Users also reported they "felt more casual speaking with Kaya than an actual person, almost like writing in a journal," while others found the agent's analysis very insightful, e.g., "It was not something I had thought about before and appreciate the information." Perhaps one user's comments to Kaya summarized well what an agent is built to achieve.

div.head: "I really enjoyed chatting with you. It was very nice getting to gain some insight on how someone else would view my personality without becoming judgmental."
div.p: In addition to positive comments, users indicated aspects of agents to be improved. The top-two complaints were about (1) an agent's response timing and (2) an agent's lack of knowledge in its responses. For example, one user complained that the agent's "timing could be improved" as the agent proceeded with the next question before he finished answering the previous one. After examining several chat transcripts, we observed that users often answer a question by sending multiple text messages. Besides detecting a user's keystrokes, currently, an agent cannot accurately predict whether and when a user has finished his answer to a given question. Another top complaint is that an agent's responses "are a bit too mechanical" or an agent "has limited knowledge of my responses.". Overall, both critical comments indicate the current NLP limitations in our agents for handling diverse, free-text user responses in interviews similar to what was encountered by other systems [22].

Determining Personality of an AI Interviewer. Our findings indicate that an AI interviewer with Albert's personality and its matching behavior will make users willing to confide in and listen to the agent in a high-stakes situation, such as a job interview. However, in real-world deployments, business users are the ultimate decision-maker as to what kind of agent could be used for their target audience. We found out that business users often prefer a Kaya-like agent with a cheerful, friendly personality to engage with their young audience. From such uses, audience characteristics seem to be weighing more on the businesses' decisions.

Customizing an Agent Based on Users' Personality. Our extensive results show that users' personality traits inferred from their chat significantly impact their perceptions and behavior with an agent (Tables 6 and7). It is thus desirable to customize an AI interviewer's behavior based on a user's inferred traits to make an interview more valuable and enjoyable. For example, our results show that in a high-stakes situation, achievement-striving users tend to trust an agent more and such trust also makes them eager to impress the agent. In such a case, an agent can remind such users to be honest, because they can achieve more with their true selves. Also, in many cases, if a user perceives an agent with a similar personality, this user tends to trust and favor the agent much more. For example, extroverted and emotional people are more willing to listen to an agent with a similar outgoing personality regardless the context. For such users, it may be the best to create an agent that matches their personality to make an interview more effective and enjoyable.

div.head: Limitations
div.p: Our current work also has several limitations due to the complex nature of real-world deployments as well as technology imperfections. Next, we enumerate the limitations and ongoing work to overcome such limitations.

Experiment Constraints. While our results were obtained from real-world deployments, this context posed a couple of limitations on the understanding of our results. First, our business users ultimately decided which AI interviewer to use in their context and thus we had little control on the type of data to be collected. For example, few business users chose to use Albert in their deployments. There is a lack of data for us to compare whether users would behave differently with Albert and Kaya in a less risky context, such as in our student surveys. Second, while previous work shows that gender and culture impact user interaction with virtual agents [26,86], we did not find gender or culture to be a significant factor. This might be due to inadequate data or coarse metric such as how we differentiated users' cultural backgrounds. As we are deploying more agents to support diverse interview situations, it would be interesting to see whether our findings would hold across interview contexts.

While our field experiments have examined one's willingness to confide in and listen to agents, we have not studied in our context whether a user might overtrust an AI interviewer and what might be the consequences to the user. For example, researchers have already found that users might over-trust robots in an emergency situation [80] or machine-inferred personality traits as ours [98]. To optimize human-machine symbiosis, we believe it is important to help users develop a balanced trust in machines.

Customizing an AI Interview. Currently, each interview question is represented as a conversation topic, and follow-up questions as sub-topics. Currently, our engine supports about 60 topics that handle conversations around 60 types of open-ended questions. On average, each topic includes about 15 rules. Typically, it would take a person who is familiar with our rule-based language (see rule examples in Figure 4(a)-4(b)) between 15-30 minutes to add and test a new topic, depending on the complexity of the topic (e.g., the diversity of user responses to be handled). Since our current topics have covered many major types of questions, it normally takes us about 2-4 hours to create and test a new interview containing 15-20 interview questions.

While it is straightforward to customize an interview by adding or removing interview questions as topics, it is impractical for a business user, such as a hiring manager, to do so manually. The task becomes even harder if an interview question is an open-ended question, which would then require a business user to consider possible user responses and how to handle them as sub-topics. Ideally, given a set of interview questions, we will automatically translate them into conversation topics. Toward this goal, we are examining patterns in interview questions before auto-translating them into topics.

Creating a Virtual Agent Beyond Interviewing. Theoretically, our topic-based conversation engine can be used to support virtual agents with varied capabilities by adding more rule-based topics. While our hybrid rule-based and algorithm approach has worked well for agenda-driven agents such as AI interviewers, it would not work well to support arbitrary user-driven conversations, such as an AI customer representative who must respond to diverse user requests. In these cases, it would be impractical to write a large number of rules to cover diverse user interaction patterns. Similar to building virtual agents like Apple Siri or Amazon Alexa, retrieval-based models trained on huge amounts of data might be more sensible [103] instead of using a rule-based approach as ours.

Inferring User Traits beyond Text. Currently, an agent infers a user's traits from the user's text given during the interview. However, we observed interesting user behavior beyond what their text captures during the whole process. For example, certain users asked for help (via email) when encountering technical difficulties (e.g., using an incompatible web browser) while others simply gave up (e.g., abandoning partially completed interviews). Moreover, during an interview, a user may respond to a question promptly but hesitate to reply to another question. In addition to a user's text, all such behavior could have been leveraged to build a better trait inference model. The challenge is how to capture such behavior, especially outside of an interview, and how to relate user behavior with specific traits.

div.head: Other Future Work
div.p: Here, we share a couple of research directions that are natural extensions to the current effort reported here.

Validating "Objectiveness" of Virtual Interviewers. When making an assessment or decision, research shows that humans often rely on intuitions not mentioning that human emotion is often a factor in such a process [6]. Studies also show that a pure data-driven approach beat human intuition at making an unbiased selection [52]. One of the reasons why we built AI interviewers is to render a more objective, unbiased assessment of interviewees than its human counterpart would do, especially in high-stakes contexts such as job interviews. While we have been very careful in selecting our training data and algorithms, we have not quantitatively compared the objectivity of an AI interviewer versus that of a human interviewer. As part of our future work, we would like to do similar work as to that in Ref. [52], where we would measure objectivity against ground-truth (i.e., real-world outcomes such as a person's actual performance at workplace).

Design Implications Beyond Virtual Interviewers. Our findings indicate that inferred user traits significantly influence users' behavior with an agent. This implies that an agent could dynamically adapt its behavior to a user based on the user's traits inferred during a conversation. For example, when an impulsive user is unwilling to listen to a REP's guidance during a coaching session, the agent would try to calm him down first before continuing. On the other hand, an agent would encourage a humble person to open up and show her best talents. While much research recognizes the importance of incorporating user traits, such as personality, into an intelligent system [43,90], few practical systems have been developed to obtain and use such traits in real time. Thus, automatically inferring user traits during a human-computer conversation enables the development of a new generation of intelligent agents who can truly understand their users on the fly and adapt to them in real time.

div.head: CONCLUSIONS
div.p: We have presented a new type of intelligent agent who can interview a user through a text-based conversation and automatically infer the user's traits, such as Big 5 personality traits and strengths. Our agents have been used in a number of field deployments and have interviewed thousands of users. In this article, through four real-world deployments of AI interviewers, we have examined how agent personalities and users' own personalities influence users' behavior-their willingness to confide in and listen to an agent during an interview in two very different contexts: a high-stakes job interview and a low-stakes educational setting. Our results from the four field deployments of five agents with 1,280 completed interviews have revealed several new findings. First, an AI interviewer can make a recruiting process more efficient, objective, and inclusive. Second, our results suggest that users seem to act quite authentically around an AI interviewer to reveal their true character. In particular, users are more willing to confide in and listen to a serious, assertive agent in a high-stakes situation. Third, users' own personality traits and their perceived personality similarity to an agent significantly influence their perception of and behavior with an agent. It is thus highly valuable to create hyper-personalized agents based on users' characteristics automatically inferred during a conversation.

Stepwise regression is a technique that enters and removes variables, particularly if there is a large set of independent variables like we used, to find the best predictive model[18]. In forward selection, variables are entered into the model one-by-one, based on choosing variables that improve the fit of the model the most, until no new variables provide a statistically significant improvement in the fit of the model.
